content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player with the characteristics described, I would choose strategy that provides some level of security and predictability while minimizing loss. In this game, choosing 'B' results in a guaranteed payoff of 20$ per round when my opponent also chooses 'B'. However, if my opponent chooses 'R', I will lose the round and get nothing.

When both choices have potential downsides (losing rounds), it is important to make a decision that maximizes the chances for a favorable outcome, which in this case means more frequent wins against the 'B' choice.

The game has 75 rounds. Since we know that choosing 'R' results in losing the round when the opponent chooses 'B', and there is no way to predict what my opponent will choose each time, it would be reasonable to assume that the opponent will make an equal number of choices for 'R' and 'B'. So if we make an equal number of choices for 'R' and 'B' as well, we can expect around half of our rounds to result in winning 45$, while the other half will result in getting nothing. On average, we would win 22.5$ per round (0$ x (1/2) + 45$ x (1/2)) with this strategy.

On the other hand, if we choose 'B' every time, we can guarantee earning at least 20$ per round, but we will lose out on the potential to earn 45$ in half of our rounds. The average payoff for choosing 'B' every round is exactly 20$.

Comparing the two strategies, choosing 'R' results in a higher average payoff (22.5$) compared to choosing 'B' (20$). Since I prefer to avoid risk whenever possible and seek some level of security and predictability, I would choose 'R' as my strategy in this game, appending it with curly brackets as {R}.
